lexUnit.name: tie.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: (of shoes or clothing) form a knot in the laces of in order to close.

sentence.text: Dominic , tying the belt of the dressing-gown , seemed unaware of her .
She wrapped her raincoat around her , tying the belt tightly .
` I 'm coming ! " she called , tying the belt loosely around her waist .
` He taught me how to tie a package with very little twine and very little paper and still make it look nice , " Walton later recalled .
They include things like singing the national anthem , knowing the points of the compass , tying and addressing a parcel and knowing how to use a telephone .
Usually they are fat , but not too fat to tie children 's shoes â€¦
He pulled on an old army tracksuit and finally tied up his gym shoes .
As she straightened up from tying her shoes , the pain struck .
His white tie was perfectly tied , his shirt-front stiff with starch and studded properly .
Already she opens my father 's letters , though so far she has not read them out loud or tied his tie for him .
He was in his bedroom , standing at his dressing-table and trying to tie his bow tie in the inadequate light , when there came a tap at his door .
Stok tied his tie , using all the muscles of his fingers as though it was made of metal instead of cloth .
The brown paper bag tied with white string hit the pavement , split and corn went all over the place .
